name: The Escapists
description: The Escapists provides players the opportunity of experiencing a light-hearted insight into everyday prison life with the main objective being that of escaping!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP Processor: Dual Core CPU 2.4 gHz Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: Intel HD Graphics 4000, Nvidia GeForce 8000, ATI Radeon HD 4800 Series Storage: 2 GB available space Sound Card: Windows Compatible Card Additional Notes: We recommend updating your PC's hardware drivers before playing. If your PC is no longer supported by your manufacturer and your hardware drivers are very old, you may experience difficulty running the game. Please check with your PC manufacturer for more details.

reviews.review_text: Awesome!Just some suggestions...  Great game in general, though a little tedeous at times. I think everything in this game is perfect except for one thing...  Make this game multiplayer. Imagine escaping prisons with your friends and working together. i personally think that would be AWESOME! So add that.

Chipping trough walls with plastic forks. Crafting make-shift weapons. Scouting out the prison. Getting the right items. Dodging guards. Living prison life. Getting keymolds. Getting better jobs. Leveling stats. Getting a guard outfit. Covering up dug holes and chipped walls. Finnaly getting out to the perimiter wall. Get shot by a guard in a tower, taking all your items and putting you into solitary. Trying again. Succes. Reliazie this was the easiest prison, and a even harder one awaits you.  Sounds like fun? It is fun.  Pros:  - 6 defualt prisons, along side 2 custom. (3 if you had early acces) - A sea of non-craftable and craftable items. - A easy to understand crafting system. - A helpfull and lovely community. - Amazing soundtrack. - The abillity to name all guards and in-mates. - 9001 ways to escape the prison. - Very polished and alsmost bug free. -PRISON EDITOR  Cons:   - Very rage inducing.   So all in all, The Escapist is an amazing game and should be played at all costs. Fun and compelling, challenging and extrmely high quality. Easy to get into, hard to master. Well, I am off to see if my plan works this time.  10/10

This is a game about escaping from various prisons. The 'levels' are the prisons.  I like the old-school pixel graphics. The GUI is incredibly fast and responsive. Controlling the little guy that tries to escape is a fun challenge. I like how you have to think out a plan and can bide your time to execute it. The independent lives of the other inmates is fun, and they can also give you missions and objects to use.  The mouse-clicking for moving objects can be a bit finnicky, I would prefer the option of using the keyboard for everything. Also knowing which things can be crafted into what (like a bar of soap + sock = a weapon) could be more discoverable in-game.  It's a pretty polished and fun game.

A very polished and clever experience, but it seems that there is usually only one way to escape. It would be nice if future maps included more than one way to escape, and a reward for escaping in every way from one prison. Other than that, just damn fun to play. Good now, even better when Multiplayer rolls out.

The Escapists happens to be a very well-built game, but like all games, has it's fair share of flaws.  Pros    Very fun    Gives you an achievement for flooding 30 toilets    Comes with a prison designer (also known as the 'Map Editor') so you can make your own levels and send them to the world   Cons    Can become tedious after a while    Your stats deteriorate a bit too quickly    The officers sometimes become suspicious when you're doing nothing wrong whatsoever   Overall, The Escapists is worth playing, and the addition of a mode where you play as an officer would be a very welcome one. After all, it would be fun to learn just what the officers do offscreen.

Do favors for inmates, assault them, assault the Correctional Officers (if you dare), make an honest prisoner's wage, buy materials, steal materials, make alliances, whatever it takes to survive and escape! Break a hole in the wall all Andy Dufrane-like, cover it with a poster, dig a tunnel and hope you come out clean on the other side!   Do not miss this one!

There are certain games that most everyone likes but just don't capture you for some reason. It's often not the fault of the game but just a bad marriage between game and gamer.   So it is with me and The Escapists. To be honest, I don't get it. There's no direction, the art style is best phrased as butt-ugly and the controls aren't easy. I'm forever getting stuck on the edge of doors because you have to be lined up perfectly to get through them. I don't find the gameplay very compelling.   I know what I'm supposed to do - work on your stats, get into a job that allows you to steal the components you need to escape and then do so - but I don't find it very engaging. In that I know I'm in the minority. That's ok. I'm just not good at it. The side quests are simple, the other prisoners seem to be fairly faceless, the routine dull and just the whole thing for me falls flat. I haven't even been able to escape the first prison and to tell you the truth it's not really worth my time trying. I should like it - I'm a fan of strategy - but I don't.   Now again, that's just my experience. But I also know I'm not the only one. A friend of mine also bought this and felt the exact same way. In the meanwhile the reviews are very positive, so I know and accept that I'm in the minority.   Yeah, if this sounds like the classic 'it's not you, it's me' line, it pretty much is. I'd probably like the game much more if the controls were better, if the graphics are clearer and if the strategy was more robust. But it's not and I regret buying this one. If returns were allowed when I bought it, I would have done so. But they weren't and so it gets a thumbs down from me. YMMV.

I have been eyeing this game for quite a while, in fact almost since it was initially released. I was really excited once I actually bought it. Then I played it.   The game has an amazing idea, fun graphics, and a lot going for it. As you can tell by most of the reviews people like it. There are a lot of things that ruined the game for me.  First off, there isn't a real tutorial. It doesn't teach you anything of real importants, in fact the tooltips throughout the game do more than the tutorial. It took me over ten minutes to figure out how to lift weights in the exercise room, and I only figured it out because I went online looking for help on a wiki.   Second, many of the mechanics of the game are not very rewarding, nor very interesting. To raise your strength, you have to smash down on your a key for several hours before you can start to take on even another inmate, which leaves your finger aching and you a little frustrated. Then running to build up your movement speed is a similar situation, just a little less button mashy after you build it up during your workout. It's fun to start tunneling or exploring the vent systems, except the guards have x-ray vision and as soon as they find anything out of the ordinary it's your fault. In fact I remember one time I was just sleeping and I got caught when I had a fake vent up (Which is supposed to be fool proof by the way.) So the game mechanics weren't super well thought out, and could get a good fix. It would be awesome if the guards didn't have good vision and if you have mutliple ways you're trying to escape from, they only get rid of the one they found, or you could get other prisoner's caught for something you did, such as build a tunnel in their room while they're not in it. In other words, I would love if the game actually was more realistic, and less, you get fat overnight if you forgot to work out one day because stealing stuff and all, as well as less button mashing (bad for my fingers and potentially for my keyboard too.) and guards that weren't all seeing gods in mortal bodies.   The game had a lot of potential and could have been something ground breaking, except they shortcutted through a lot of the functions, making the game more frustrating and ridiculous than immersive. If there was a reboot or update to this game to fix several of these mechanics, I would most definitely get it.

oh, the escapists. it's a love/hate relationship between you and me.  you play as a little prisoner who was sent to jail for an unidentified reason, and you must collect materials to slowly, yet sneakily break out. the escapists is a prison simulator that can really test your ability to be sneaky and stuff.  there are about 6 maps currently, which range between difficulty. the hardest, being HMP Irongate, that isbased on alcatraz. (You know, the prison on the island in san fransisco?)  you can buy materials off of other prisoners too, but only with money, which can be earned by doing a favour for a prisoner (like beating up 'this' person) or doing your job. your prisoner starts off with puny stats, and you can improve these by going on a treadmill or doing push ups. Also going on the internet raises your 'intelligence' so you can craft better items and apply for better paying jobs.  I really like this game, but i hope for more to it in the future.  8/10

Games that expect you to use a wiki to figure everything out are not my thing, and the systems in this game are designed in a way that makes me feel gross.  You find crafting recipes or buy them with character-specific dollars, and your 'crafting recipes found' journal is per-character. This makes me feel like I have no progression because I want to start a new character if I end up hating the layout of the loot and how I've done on my current character and I always start from square 1 with the crafting stuff.  There is only one prison until you beat that first one, and beating the first one is a hell of a task. This means if you ♥♥♥♥ up on the first one 25 times and start to get sick of the exact same routines and level layout every time you are SOL unless you manage to beat it or play the other two, much harder prisons that are unofficial.  The fullscreen on 16:9 monitors is just the normal aspect ratio of the game stretched grossly wide, like an emulator set to stretch an NES game to 1080p that makes Mario twice as fat. It's really terrible and is the only option.  The emergent gameplay of the prison is minor and less deep than it seems at the outset. You can easily knock out any prisoner by hitting them once and then running them into a guard while they chase you, let them hit you once and then the guard beats them to unconsciousness. You can make people miss their quota for their job by beating them up a bunch during work hours and then take their job. You can plant contraband in their cells. You can make people hate you and then coax them into fighting you and use them to cause a distraction or go somewhere they wouldn't. These things are kind of cool. But not enough to base a game around.  If you fight a guard, all you can do is knock them out for 30 seconds, and if you take one of their keys they immediately game over you when they wake up. Also, if you run away after beating them up sometimes they just forget, sometimes there is no repercussion, sometimes they chase you around forever, and sometimes an unseen sniper in the corner of the map will shoot you in the face until you die. Which of these four things happens is decidedly random.  Escaping, the whole point of the dang game, sucks. Digging is this awful minecrafty thing where you have pickaxes or pickaxe-like items that very quickly decay as you use them to dig through a foot of dirt, and then when they break you have to go get more. Tools you need desperately are either totally randomly found, difficult to craft with no way to figure out how the recipes work, which have some amount of sense, but, come on, paper meche = toilet paper & super glue? People who have played the early access version rattle off absurd, stupid crafting items like a 'bed decoy' and 'fake vent cover' that just scream that the game's systems are buried so deep in their own BS that they feel the need to overdesign to cover their own flaws. Why build a game where you need three tiers of pickaxes and bed roll decoys and cell curtains and instant death snipers? Silliness.  Vital items are hidden in one-time random loot crates that disappear forever after finding them and can contain garbage or incredibly valuable things and the seed changes every time you load so you have to save scum if you want something in particular.  Oh and all the text stuff is all over the place in grammar and spelling, full of memes and nonsense most of the time, and you read it all within the first few hours. Sure there's some neat ideas but pulled off in a way that feels very mediocre.  I still find myself coming back and might revise this review. It's kind of fun in some ways but just so frustrating.

Great im going to try give an accurate guide on how to escape the first prison (very easy)  1. train up your HP to 100% (untill your hp is 50)  2. train your intellect a bit 3. get a metalshop job (this is the job you get paid most for)  4. fill your desk with forks and knives get a screw driver too  5. move your desk so you can climb the vent in your cell  6. at night time use the knives to weaken the vent to 5% durability (dont let the guards see) use your scredriver to finish off the vent (it should appear in your inventory) make sure to place a bed dummy (this is really important) cover up the vent too 7. search for loot 8. steps 4 5 6 and 7 were optional so if you don't want to bother you dont need to  9. get 2 pieces of timber and some green wire  10. craft nunchucks (powerfull weapon) 11. get some rope  12. get a guard outfit  13. during free time knock out guards when they are alone and strolling by themselves 14. tie them up with the rope  15. knock out all the guards you can 16. tie them up with rope if you have some  17. you should get a letter from the warden about the main gate being open 18. put on the guard uniform 19. walk through the front gate like a boss 20. you've escaped and should've got a achievement have fun guys ;)

Read more negative reviews or watch some gameplay video before buying this game.  Mostly a let down, it doesnt simulate anything very well and nothing is explained. I played it to long to get a refund but most of my time on it was not having fun. I might try to continue going to see if it gets better as I learn more but so far it is very lack luster.  Although it is claimed that there are lots of ways you co do things almost anything you try will fail due to illogical AI  Here are some examples.  All gaurds carry various keys but you can't pick pocket them and none of them go to the main gate. If you knock out a gaurd and take a key then run and hide, when he wakes up you will be magically teleported to solitary confinment without them finding you.  Stashing contraban in another prisoners cell does not get them in trouble.  Also no one can permantly die, you don't have an actual sentence or anything and there is no long term repercussions for good or bad behaivore just a bit a skill drop if you spend the night in solitary,  It's hard to explain in text but the game just feels stifling and pointless.  There is no shake downs or lock downs. After about 3 hours it becomes rather apparent how repetitive the gameplay is. The game is very reliant on RNG for deciding what items appear, which means you'll spend a lot of time waiting for the right items to appear to stea/buy to craft whatever you need. It also highly encourages you to follow the same routine every day (which I wouldn't mind as much if it wasn't pure button mashing).  In some instances the game will instantly teleport you to solitary confinement for certain behaviours which is pretty frustrating considering you'll lose most of your crafted items in your inventory. This wouldn't be as bad if the saves you can load back to didn't all start at the beginning of the day (meaning you have to repeat the daily routine all over again).

As a few people have highlighted, there are some major flaws in the gameplay on this game. Its a nicely put together title in the 8-bit format, and it reacts as you would expect in terms of interface. But the issue here is with the gameplay which is the main focus for 8-bit format titles. The instant bust is a killer in terms of your trial and error attempts to escape. The main issue being where you hide your contraband in that any point you are busted doing anything escape like your entire cell and stash is taken.  hiding stash in vent shafts can work but you need a ton of fake vents on hand as there is no warning when they will and at a night you then have no chance to fix it and again lose all your stuff.   Let alone snipers picking you off in the middle of the cell block and keys being traced back to you?!?!  Some of the failings (and this is on the first level mind!) are just too tough to get around especially when learning the game. The issue that you can only save at night (when you want to put your plans in action) means to save you need to wait a whole other day then try again. Why not just add a quick save and let people play and try to beat the game!?  Anyway its an alright title but with some major frustrations that once you lose a days play there isn't enough in the game to make me go back and keep repeating it - and on that front for the money i can't recommend it.,..

If you're looking for a positive review, then you're in the wrong place, HOWEVER, if you're here for a tremendous chicken Stir Fry recipe, THEN LOOK NO FURTHER!  - Serves 4 - 10 mins to prepare and 10 mins to cook - 325 calories / serving - Healthy  INGREDIENTS:  - 1 orange, zested and juiced - 2tbsp soy sauce - 2tbsp sesame oil - 250g (8oz) tender stem broccoli - 5cm (2in) piece root ginger - 1tbsp sunflower oil - 1 garlic clove, finely sliced - 1 red pepper, deseeded and thinly sliced - 150g Straight To Wok Noodles - 400g (13oz) chicken fillet, cut into thin slices  METHOD  Step 1 - Mix together the orange zest and juice, soy sauce and sesame oil and set aside.  Step 2 - Blanch the broccoli in boiling water for 2 minutes, then drain well and set aside.  Step 3 - Finely shred the ginger. Then heat a large frying pan or wok, add the sunflower oil, heat it until sizzling, and fry the ginger till it's crisp.  Step 4 - When it's done, remove with a slotted spoon. Add the chicken and garlic, and stir-fry until just browned. Remove the meat using a slotted spoon and set aside.  Step 5 - Add the red pepper and broccoli and stir-fry for around 2-3 minutes until it's just tender. Add the soy sauce mixture, bring it to the boil then return the chicken to the pan and heat through. Serve with noodles.

The American Civil War was a civil war fought from 1861 to 1865, to determine the integrity of the United States of America as it defeated the bid for independence by the breakaway Confederate States of America. Among the 34 states in January 1861, seven Southern slave states individually declared their secession from the U.S. and formed the Confederate States of America. War broke out in April 1861 when they attacked a U.S. fortress, Fort Sumter, and ended with the surrender of all the Confederate armies in spring 1865.  The Confederacy, colloquially known as the South, grew to include eleven states; it claimed two more states and several western territories. The Confederacy was never diplomatically recognized by any foreign country. The states that remained loyal including border states where slavery was legal, were known as the Union or the North. The war had its origin in the factious issue of slavery, especially the extension of slavery into the western territories. Four years of intense combat left 750,000 soldiers dead, and destroyed much of the South's infrastructure. The Confederacy collapsed and slavery was abolished in the entire country. The Reconstruction Era (1863–1877) overlapped and followed the war, with its fitful process of restoring national unity, strengthening the national government, and guaranteeing civil rights to the freed slaves.

The game is pretty cool actually. Escaping from prison isn't something we see in a lot of games these days. It works on just about any system without too many problems. Gameplay and mechanics are all pretty good and the game is pretty easy to pick up and play.   However ..... this is a game that fits into the 'YouTuber Bait' genre. As good as the game is I feel its success is bulit up on being popular on YouTube and not because of how good the game is. A minor complaint to be sure, but its something for you to think about.  I still recommend it though. It tries to offer something different, instead of the same mindless first person shooter / minecraft clones. Its not a bloody rogue like and its not a metrovania style game.   Seriously though give this game a go. Worth a buy, but not at the full £12.99.

At first this game can be pretty enjoyable. Trying to figure your way out of a prison can be interesting and a real challenge. But really there are far too many problems for me to recommend.  The biggest problem, and what really forced me to stop playing is the aquisition of items.  Seriously, you can spend DAYS searching for a specific item you need to continue and at first it's easy to ignore while you do other things, but it quickly becomes a problem. Having to spend so much time just waiting for a roll of duct tape to magically appear in another inmates inventory or being unable to find the last ingredient to something gets annoying and tedious. I'm all for challenge in a game, but that's not a challenge its a wall you have to wait to get over, and that's not enjoyable.  Secondly, the game does a very poor job of giving the player information. In some ways its understandable, in others its pretty annoying. For instance, did you know you need a vent cover or else any guard who happens to wander near by will immediately spot it and throw you in solitary (confiscating all your items), that's okay, that should be a bit obvious I guess. But did you know you could cover the bars on your cell with bed sheets so they won't spot it? Did you know how to make a makeshift vent cover? No? Well good luck finding out. The best way to learn crafting rescipes is to go to the wiki, which just simply shouldn't be. You could of course try to figure out the recipes yourself, but as above you don't want to waste valuable resources experimenting you don't want to do that. You could of course buy or find the recipe and it will appear in a very unorganized list of all the recipes your character learned (a search function for the list would be fantastic).

This game is fun, it really is, and it would absolutely be a positive rating if it wasn't for a few things:  The items in this game are randomly generated, and it is TEDIOUS as all hell trying to find the one specific item you need. Its especially more tedious when it comes to the fact that the most important items needed spawn even less then the normal items. Need a book? All you will be able to find is toothpaste. Need toothpaste? All you will be able to find is books. Like, seriously. I spend more time wandering around the prison, tediously checking every inmates desk day after day trying to find one specific item than I do actually escaping the prison. There are inmates that sell items, but they seem to always sell the same items, and rarely is it anyting important.   The game also gets kind of boring pretty quick. The only really fun, heart pounding parts are when your actually escaping the prison, knowing that at any moment, you could be caught, and all your progress could be diminished. But, thats really the only good part. The rest of the game is pretty much what I mentioned above: Walking around checking inmates desks hour after hour after hour, hoping you find what you need. The 'favors' you can do for your inmates are pretty bland, pretty much consisting of 'find me this' or 'beat up this guy'.  So, in conclusion, yes, this is a great game. However, lately, I've found myself playing it less and less because I know that all I will be doing if I do play it is wandering around, checking desks for hours and hours. So, if they can fix this issue, then I will be happy to give this games a thumbs up. But, for now, I'm pretty much forced to give this game a thumbs down.

This is an amazing game, it reminds me of the 8 bit days in the most nostalgic way...  This being said it isn't a play on the nostalgia factor but instead a very well developed game (some of the diologue could be fixed up a bit for sure) but for the ammount of thought that went into the other aspects of the game this is a moot point...  From hitting first roll call to figuring out the daily routine for each prison.. Figuring out and stashing what you need... Finding out the layout of the prison and ultimately putting together and executing the perfect escape... Or being caught and starting from scratch...  By day 5 of the first prison I felt for my 8 bit character and his digital plight and by the time I finally escaped (day 14 or so the first time) I felt like I might never get out from accidentally setting myself back a couple times...   The first escape was incredibly satisfying... For all the small steps you take day to day to culminate and pay off like that... Its a beauty of a game and for anyone nervous about buying an 8 bit game in a world where graphical realism is becoming almost indistinguishable from a live movie... Well you'd be hard pressed to find a game that draws you in like this..  And furthermore if the dev reads this... This is my full verdict on The Escapists: I love the fact that the speech bank is completely random during rollcall- 'As I used to say to my cheating ex, someone flushed the wardens hat down the toilet' or 'As my old man used to say, I'll nod when you can speak' xD.This game is a bit costly and it gets a bit fustrating with the trail-and-error on every prison you go to and bang up in solitary confinement countless times (Also the stats for intelligence,strength and speed decrease too fast) but other than that The Escapists is a fun, colurful and creative game with so many awesome ways to escape the prison-My favoutite method is to disable all the cameras and bash the guards lights out (This method is callled a prison takeover). I also like the well thought out routines to keep the players from breaking out on the first day and I love the exercise machines which change on every prison( My personal favourite is the speed bags). It also has a wide variety of items to craft with over 16 pages worth of items in your crafting journal and the items that you usually find in desks or prisoner stashes. There need to be more prisons though but you can create your own prison with the level editor (I have made 1 or 2 decent prisons but the rest should be burned). I give this awesome game 8.7/10!( I still can't get past Shankton State Pen, though).

I love every last detail about this game. The only thing bad is the frustration of getting a certain item, which makes you want to play it even more! I've currently escaped the first four prisons, and the fifth one is getting me angry, but, this game is worth the $17.99 plus three DLC's   99.9999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999999909/100

Holy Hardness! This game is hard! But it's good.   Okay first off, Gameplay. This game has okay gameplay. It's not bad, it just isn't amazing. You wake up, do a rollcall, eat breakfeast, get free period, and so on. It's simple. But after buying two screwdrivers and a file, a cookie, and a bed dummy, you go up a vent an escape! Sadly, you have to google many things to fully understand the game, but after that, the game is good! It is hard, but in three hours, I escaped Center Perks. The soundtrack is awesome! The only freaky one was the lockdown song. By the way, I once got stuck in a vent all night, and they had a lockdown. It scared the heck outta me! They never found me, so I had to delete the save file and start a new one.    In all, the game isn't worth $18, but it is a good enough game to stop your boredom and have a nice experience while it's a rainy day. 8/10

'Whu - wait. Where am I?'  'Ssshhh! The guards will hear you!'  'I don't understand, where am I?'  'This is Alcatraz, mate. We're the criminals who got sent here. Don't you remember?'  'No! What's going on?'  'Well, we have to break out of this place and get back to the mainland. I could use the help of someone like you. Are you in?'  'Well, if it means getting out of here, then very well. What do I do?'  'Our first mission is to create a place to store all our stuff. I'll get a fork at breakfast and scrape a hole in the wall.'  'Very funny... wait, you can do that?'  'Of course! But don't ever do it when the guards are watching.'  'Right. What next?'  'We need to start getting items from people. Do jobs for people, get money, and try not to get caught. That can be your job.'  'Why do I have to do that?'  'Because you're the newest guy here! Anyway, the best time to steal items from people is after you've done your chores - you've got to do the laundry.'  'What if someone sees me stealing?'  'Well, you get beaten up. Actually, a lot of this escape involves either beating other people up or getting beaten up.'  'Why do people beat me up so much?'  'Oh, it doesn't happen very much... actually scratch that, it can happen for any reason. Either you've stolen someone's soap, or you look at someone funny; even taking a spoon from the cutlery tray when people are around!'  'Just one question: are you sure we can escape?'  '... on second thoughts, no.'

At first, this game doesn't seem like anything special. Sure, it's a well-constructed prison sim. Anything else? You go around collecting contraband, crafting weapons and tools for your eventual escape. You beat up guards and inmates every once and a while (unless you're planning on being released for good behavior), and end up feeling pretty OP.  Then, it comes time to break out. This is when the anxiety and paranoia come in. Honestly, just the atmosphere in this game, and the feel of it. . .it's very hard to explain. But while you're escaping, your heart will start to speed up, your hands will get sweaty, the slightest movement by the patrolling guards will freak you out. Any noise will make you jump all the way to the moon. There's something about this game that just captures the feeling of knowing you're doing something naughty, and that you don't want to be caught. It FEELS like you're actually escaping.  12/10 amazing game!

The escapists is a very good game. The idea is amazing, it has very well polished with not much missing from the game. On that note I do belive that the developers could spend a little more time taking community ideas that have popular support and implementing them into the game. The ingame prison creator is very well suited for the game and I would very much like to see an installment of it in The Escapists 2. This game is a great play and worth the buy, even if a few more updates could make the game have a sharper edge.  EDIT: I rewrote this review. When I wrote this review I was pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ with other developers and expressed my hatred into this review, I have updated it to express my real opnions on the game, and hopefully I will have a similar if not better opinion for the next installment of The Escapists.

It's a good but hard game, but it feels really wierd in its punishments... when you make the tiniest of mistakes, you lose everything, which makes sense (frustrating as it is)... but then it gives you an option to revert to an old save? Make up your mind, are you gonna punish players or let them have immunity from harm?  I feel like the savesystem itself could be changed to solve this problem. I think it should autosave frequently. The game as it is puts very little strain on your PC, so I feel like it can get away with autosaving after every time the period changes or maybe even less. Along side this, I feel it should autosave when you're caught. This would in my oppinion make the game harder, and also make it so I don't have to just leave the game running minimized when I stop playing partway through a day. I feel like this sort of savesystem should at least be added as an optional feature for those who want it (like a hardcore mode).  If this was added I'd feel that the game would be even better.
